abstracts.cdata!:
The Enterprise Incubator Project (EIF)
            of Armenia had the following ratings: outcomes were
            satisfactory, risk to development outcome was negligible to
            low, Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and
            borrower performance was satisfactory. The lessons learned
            included: 1) The enhanced incubator model tested during the
            project seems to be an appropriate vehicle for addressing
            the market failures in the Armenia's IT sector; 2)
            According to sample company data, the service package most
            in demand in Armenia's IT industry seems to be a
            combination of business services and training, in both
            technical aspects of the IT industry and in sales and
            promotion; 3) With hindsight, the original design of
            including a control group to test the impact of an incubator
            enhanced with business services and training may not have
            been necessary; 4) A Learning and Innovation Loan (LIL) is
            probably not the most appropriate vehicle for launching any
            future enterprise incubators based on the experience with
            EIF, particularly since there already has been considerable
            global experience with them; 5) It is better not to define
            pre-set packages of services in designing an enterprise
            incubator project, due to the diversity of company needs,
            even within the same sector, and instead allow the service
            packages to emerge from the market place, hiring experts as
            needed and using surveys to assess the needs of potential
            clients; 6) The usual design of the PAD does not provide
            enough up-front attention to the learning hypothesis and its
            linkage to the development objectives and monitoring
            indicators; 7) The lack of sufficient quality control for a
            LIL, in the absence of the reviews required for Board
            presentation, essentially transfers the appraisal work to
            the implementation stage, and this can cause delays that may
            jeopardize the outcome of the project; 8) In defining a
            monitoring framework, in order to keep the focus on the main
            objective, it is important to clarify the hierarchy and
            inter-relationships of final outcome indicators and
            intermediate indicators; and 9) Any future incubator project
            including a building donated or rented by the Government
            should be in place before the start of the project and
            therefore should be a condition of effectiveness.

5081800.trustfund:
TF026172-PHRD-PRIVATE SECTOR DEVELOPMENT
            PROJECT (BANK-EXECUTED),TF030488-JAPAN CTF - FY04 GENERAL: ECA
            (ALL COUNTRIES IN EUROPE AND CENTRAL ASIA,TF025354-PHRD-PRIVATE SECTOR DEVELOPMENT PROJ.(RECIPIENT-EXECUTED),TF030454-AUSTRIA GENERAL CTF FY04 - ECA
5081800.majtheme: Financial and private sector development,Human development

abstracts.cdata!:
The Enterprise Incubator (LIL) Project
            will help unlock the institutional rigidities that hinder
            the development of Armenia's human capital, in
            particular, as it relates to the business environment, so as
            to prod economic growth. The project design reflects the
            approach of encouraging creativity, experimentation, and
            accountability management, thus its components call for: 1)
            financing the telecommunication infrastructure needed to
            house high-tech companies, and information technology (IT).
            To this end, local area networks will be linked to a
            hi-speed internet service provider, and communications
            hardware/software, while services will be related to a
            distance learning center equipped with computerized teaching
            aids, which will be offered to local and medium size
            enterprises - first preference being IT business - based on
            available business plans; 2) provision of a business
            services center, to assure current market demands for IT
            skills, by financing consulting services for development of
            a business plan formulation, including operational costs, as
            well as managerial, and senior staff placement costs, at
            countries or regions with export oriented IT sectors, and by
            enhancing basic management, and business communications
            skills; 4) provision of on-demand technical training, by
            supporting professional education, through training
            programs, and extensive knowledge for emerging business
            entities, in cooperation with the Skills Development
            Facility, and, entrepreneurship grants will cover initial
            business investment costs; and, 5) provision of financial,
            accounting, and procurement support, through technical
            assistance, and consulting services.
